Yolanda dreams of being able to give her all her children a good, high quality education through all her hard work on her business. Every week, she faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work and draw strength and inspiration from her studies of the Word of God. 


* All CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. Fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy fruit to sell

loans.name: Apollo

texts.en:
Apollo is 30 years old and lives in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has one child. For the past four years, Apollo has been working hard to manage his stationery store, which sells office supplies and offers photocopying services. 

To help expand his business, Apollo has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stationery supplies, and will help Apollo to generate greater profits and improve the quality of life for his family. Apollo hopes that in the future he will be able to open another stationery business in town. 

Apollo is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Apollo who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more stationery supplies.

loans.name: Cristy

texts.en:
Cristy is married, 29 years of age, and has three children. She lives in Tukuran Zamboanga del Sur. Cristy owns and manages a general store to earn a living. She has had this business for more than six years. Each month she earns Php 7,000 doing this type of work. Cristy requested a loan of Php 30,000 to purchase additional products to sell. 

Cristy has been a member of GDMPC for almost one year. In the future, she hopes that her business will expand and she will be able to sustain her family’s daily needs.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Somaly

texts.en:
Somaly and her husband, Phat, live in a village about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1992 and have two sons and one daughter. One is a garment worker, another is learning sewing machine repairing skills and another stays at home.

Somaly and her husband are vegetable farmers. They used to sell firewood, but they quit the business. Somaly is asking for a loan of $500 to buy seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm. She will also use a part of the loan to pay school fees for her son, who is learning sewing machine repairing skills.

Photo: Somaly is at home, not at the farm.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm and pay school fees for her son who is learning sewing machine repairing skills.

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en: Purevsuren is a loving mother who lives with her husband and four kids in an apartment in the Govisumber province of Mongolia. Her husband is a driver, her elder two children are college students in the capital city of Mongolia, and her younger two children are school students. She runs an internet cafe business. Now that winter is approaching, she needs to replace the heating system of her work environment. She is requesting 500,000 MNT to replace the heating system. She is a sharp and diligent woman who says, "It is hard to handle two kids college fees, however, I will not step back and I will not rest until my youngest kid graduates college."

loans.use: to replace a heating system.

loans.name: Sophorn

texts.en:
Sophorn, 31, is a garment worker and her husband, Phivann, 33, is a tuk tuk taxi driver. They have been married for 11 years and have one son and one daughter. One is in school and the other is still young. The family lives in a village about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sophorn is in the process of building her new house, but it is not finished yet. Hence she is asking for a loan of $1,200 to make the finishes.

loans.use: To finish building her house.

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina (pictured with her loom) is a weaver, while her husband, Vanny, is a horse cart driver. They live on an island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City and have three sons and one daughter. Three are in school and the other is still young. 

Dina is asking for a loan of $200 to continue her weaving business by purchasing weaving materials.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.en: Rodolfo is married with 4 kids. He is 45 years old and resides in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. Rodolfo owns and operates a fish selling venture to make a living, and has had this business for more than 3 years. Each month, he earns PHP 7,000 doing this type of work. Since he fully repaid his previous loan last year, he has requested a new loan in the amount of PHP 10,000 to purchase new fishing equipment and fish to sell. Rodolfo has been a member of GDMPC for more than 2 years. Rodolfo wishes that his business will grow, and his living conditions will also be good.

loans.use: to purchase new fishing equipment and fish to sell.

loans.name: Phanny

texts.en:
Phanny, 41, is a motor taxi driver and his wife, Kimseng (pictured with him), 36, is a farmer. They live about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have two sons and one daughter. One is a garment worker, one is in university and another one is in high school.

Phanny is applying for a loan of $1,200 to assist in his wife’s farming business by buying seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm. He will also use a part of the loan to pay school fees for his son who is in university.

loans.use: To assist in his wife’s farming business by buying seed, fertilizer and pesticide and to pay school fees for his son.

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida is 31 years old and lives in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, three of whom are currently in school. For the past seven years, Farida has been working hard to manage her boutique, which sells clothes such as blouses, skirts, and traditional Ugandan dresses called gomesis. 

To help expand her business, Farida has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more materials to make clothes, and will help Farida to generate greater profits and to improve the quality of life for her family. Farida hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another boutique in town. 

Farida is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Farida who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase materials to make clothes.

loans.name: Muyassar

texts.ru: Муяссар честная и умная женщина. Она замужем, любящая мать троих детей. Она занимается скотоводством более 9 лет и имеет хорошего опыта в этом бизнесе. Муяссар начинала деятельность из одного быка и сейчас она имеет три голов коровы. Муяссар хочет расширить свой бизнес и улучшить свое жилищное условия. Она хочет, чтобы её любящие дети не видели трудности и бедности в жизни. С этой целью она направляется вперед, чтобы осуществить желание своих детей. Она хотела бы получит займ для покупки крупного рогатого скота с целью расширения бизнеса. Она заранее благодарна вам за вашу доброту и милосердие. Спасибо вам за такие возможности, которые предоставляете нам.
texts.en: Muyassar is an honest and smart woman.  She is married and is a loving mother of three children.  She has been involved in animal husbandry for over nine years and has a good experience in this business.  Muyassar started her business with one bull and now has three heads of cattle.  Muyassar wants to expand her business and improve her living conditions.  She wants to ensure that her beloved children do not see hardships and poverty in life.  To achieve this goal and fulfill her children's wishes, Muyassar is moving ahead.  She wants to obtain a loan for the purchase of cattle in order to expand her business.  She thanks you in advance for your kindness and mercy.  Thank you for these possibilities that you offer us.

loans.use: to buy cattle in order to expand her business

loans.name: Enhtuya

texts.en: Enhtuya is a loving mother of two. She lives with her husband and two kids in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent, in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. Her husband helps with her business, and her two kids are college students. She started her retail dairy business in 2004 by renting a counter in the market. Through her business, she realizes a monthly profit of 780,000 MNT. Now that winter is approaching, dairy prices will increase, so she needs to save supplies. She is a hardworking and diligent woman who says, "In order to pay two college fees, I need to work hard and do everything I can." She is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to buy milk to make dairy products.

loans.use: to buy milk to make dairy products.

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.ru: Гульбахор проживает в районе Джиликул. Она разведена. У нее четверо детей. Гульбахор уже 24 года как занимается выращиванием овощей и посевом фруктовых деревьев. Ей 42 года. Она берет кредит для покупки минеральных удобрений и семян пшеницы.
texts.en: Gulbahor lives in the Jilikul district.  She is divorced and has four children.  Gulbahor has been involved in growing vegetables and planting fruit trees for 24 years.  She is 42 years old.  She is requesting this loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers and wheat seeds.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers and wheat seeds

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam, pictured here, lives in a village about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She and her husband have two children, in addition to five children from her husband’s previous marriage. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home, two are garment workers, and the others are still young. Sam sells akor, a type of Cambodian steamed cake made of flour and sugar, in front of garment factory.  Her husband is construction worker. 

Sam is requesting her first loan of 300 USD to provide capital for her sister, who sells fish, to buy more fish to sell.

loans.use: to buy fish for her sister to sell

loans.name: Tit

texts.en:
Tit, pictured here, is 34 years old. He lives with his wife, Saman, in a village about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2000 and have two young children, a son and a daughter. Tit is a construction worker and his wife sells meat balls and sluch, a shaved ice dessert. In addition, they are also rice farmers. 

Tit is requesting a 600 USD loan to purchase seed, fertilizer, and pesticide to maintain his farm.

loans.use: to purchase seed, fertilizer, and pesticide

loans.name: Khanum

texts.en: Khanum is from the village of Erazgavors in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is divorced and has two sons (twenty-five and thirty years old).  Khanum has a high school education and technical training as a sewing specialist.  Because of the limited number of jobs in her specialty, Khanum has been farming for the past five years.  She considers herself a hardworking, honest person.  Khanum would like a loan to purchase two additional cows.  According to her business plan, this investment will increase the family income by twenty-five percent.  With future business profits, Khanum would like to renovate the family home.  She really enjoys living in Erazgavors, especially as her relatives are nearby.

loans.use: to purchase two cows

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy drugs to sell.

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.en: Guadalupe is single, 58 years old, and lives in Panaon, Misamis Occidental. She manages her own garden to make a living to cover everyday needs. She has been in this business for almost a year. Each month, she earns PHP 10,000 doing this type of work. She requested a loan in the amount of PHP 15,000 to purchase more seedlings and fertilizers. Aside from that, a portion of the loan will be used for her personal needs. Guadalupe has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. Guadalupe's future plan is to help her family and save the profit for her future.

loans.use: to purchase more seedlings and fertilizers

loans.name: Arshaluys

texts.en: Arshaluys is from the village of Keti in the Shirak region of Armenia.  He is happily married with three children – two daughters (eight and seventeen years old) and an eighteen-year-old son.  Arshaluys has a university education as an economist.  Ironically, with the difficult economic situation in Armenia, he is not working in his area of specialization.  To support his family, Arshaluys has been engaged as a farmer for the past ten years.  He is known for being a hardworking, honest person.  Arshaluys is looking for a loan to purchase livestock and feed.  He estimates that this investment will increase the family income by twenty percent.  Arshaluys wants to save enough money so his children will receive a university education.  He would also, someday, like to remodel the family home.  He likes his hometown of Keti, which has beautiful land and fresh water.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and feed

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy maize and groundnuts (peanuts) for resale

loans.name: Jora

texts.en: Jora lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Akhouryan.  He is married with three children – a twenty-one-year-old daughter and two sons (twenty-eight and thirty-five years old).  Jora has a high school education and has worked on the railway system.  Over the past twenty years, he has been working in agriculture on the family farm.  In the past couple of years, Jora has been taking microcredit loans.  He has found the terms fair and the service to be of high quality.  He would like a new loan to purchase pigs and feed.  He projects this investment will increase the family income by fifteen percent.  One of Jora’s long-term projects is to renovate the family home.  He was born in Akhouryan and enjoys the rural life.

loans.use: to purchase pigs and feed

loans.name: Tomasito

texts.en:
Tomasito is 42 years old and is married with three children. He lives in the Philippines. For the past 15 years, Tomasito has run a shop where he sells fish such as tamban, pirit, budlisan, matambaka, tilapia, and bangus. He has been a member of HSPFI since 2009.

Tomasito is requesting a 22,000 PHP loan to buy fish to sell. In the future, he hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin, a 49-year-old widower with three children, lives in Kasese, Uganda where he has operated a retail shop for 23 years. Martin started with 100,000 shillings and now has 4,000,000 shillings as his working capital. His business hardships are price fluctuation, inflation, few customers and inadequate capital.

Martin is requesting this loan to rennovate his commercial building and buy baby clothes. His business goals are to hire employees and move the business to a more permanent location, while his personal goals include educating his children and buying a car.

loans.use: to rennovate his commercial building and buy baby clothes.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita is 61 years old and is married with eight children. She lives in the Philippines. For the past 25 years, she has run a food shop or canteen where she sells snacks such as rice and pan cakes. She has been a member of HSPFI since 2009.

Margarita is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan to buy raw ingredients for making snacks. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making snacks

loans.name: Gerry

texts.en:
Due to the hardships of life, Gerry strives hard to provide for his family’s needs. He has been a farmer for more than 18 years and he plants, harvests, and sells corn. Gerry plans to improve his family’s standard of living and give them a happy life. Despite the problems and difficulties he encounters as a farmer, he has the determination to be successful someday. 

Gerry is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP to buy fertilizer and pesticides and to pay labor costs to plant corn. His loan will help a lot to improve his business. Gerry wants to increase his yields to increase his income and finance the education of his children. He hopes that, in the future, he will improve his income as he continues to work and expand his business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticide and hire farmhands

loans.name: Khasifa

texts.en:
Khasifa is 35 years old and lives in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, three of whom are currently in school. For the past ten years Khasifa has been working hard to manage her electronics shop, which sells engine oil, tubes, antennas, bulbs and electric kettles. 

To help expand her business, Khasifa has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more electronics for her shop, and will help Khasifa to generate greater profits and improve her family's welfare. Khasifa hopes that in the future she will be able to continue growing her business. 

Khasifa is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Khasifa who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more electronics for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more household products for sale.

loans.name: Lerna

texts.en:
Lerna is 59 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 1 child. 
Lerna has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for 6 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 15,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages .
Lerna has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Lerna hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Horn

texts.en: Horn is 41 years old and married with two children. She does rice farming and also raises pigs to earn additional income. She has been a farmer for 15 years. This is her first loan with VisionFund. Horn requested a loan to buy a water pump for her rice field. With this loan, she hopes to increase her crop yields and feed her pigs to be healthy and fat. She hopes to have some savings for future family expenses and also to keep her children in school.

loans.use: to purchase a water pump for her rice field

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Prey Chhor district

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: Anelita

texts.en:
Anelita is married, 41 years old with 2 kids living with her. She lives in San Apolinario, Tangub City.
She sells different kinds of vegetables like eggplant, string beans, and pumpkins to earn a living and has been in this business for more than 16 years. Each month she earns Php 3,000 doing this type of activity.

She requested a loan in the amount of Php 7,000 to purchase more vegetables to sell. She is in her 3rd loan cycle. Anelita acquired a food stall in the market where she is able to display her vegetables.

Anelita has been a member of GDMPC since 2008. In the future, Anelita is wishing that her business will prosper and plans to buy a motorcycle for vegetable delivery. She delivers vegetables to her "suki" customers (regulars).

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is 27 years old. He is married to Auma and they have four children.

Julius operates an electronics shop dealing with electrical items and appliances. He has been dealing with this business for the last six years and makes a monthly income of KES 7,000. He is taking a second loan from KADET LTD, which he will use to buy more electrical items for sale. 

He will use profits to pay back his loan without default so that he qualifies for subsequent loans. His hope is to open another electronics shop.

loans.use: To buy more electronic items to sell

loans.name: Smbul

texts.en: Smbul is from the village of Nahapetavan in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is happily married with four sons (seventeen, eighteen, twenty-one and twenty-two years old).  She has a high school education and has been working as a farmer for the past fifteen years.  Smbul supports her relatives living in the city with produce grown on her farm.  She would like to expand her business.  Smbul would like to save some of her future profits to help pay for her eldest son’s wedding.  She is looking for a loan to purchase livestock and seeds.  Smbul projects that this investment will increase the family income by fifteen percent.  She has a positive opinion of microfinance loans and likes the high quality of the service.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and seeds

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.en:
Vicenta is 51 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children. 
Vicenta has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks & vegetables like tomatoes. She has had this business for 4 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & vegetables.
Vicenta has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Vicenta hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & vegetables

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en: Aidah is 39 years old and lives in the town of Tororo, in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has three children with two of them currently in school. For the past eleven years, Aidah has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells food and home supplies to local customers. To help expand her business, Aidah has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more posho [maize flour], beans and canned soups, and will help Aidah to generate greater profits and improve the quality of life for her family. Aidah hopes that in the future she will be able to educate her children. Aidah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small business owners like Aidah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more posho, beans and canned soups

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses, a 56-year-old enterprising businessman, is married to Jane, who is a basket weaver. They are blessed with four children aged 28, 24, 20 and 16 years respectively. Supporting his family with a monthly income of KES 40,000, Moses has been a sisal farmer for the past 31 years while also running a butchery as his secondary business.

Having repaid his previous loan, Moses is applying for his second loan with KADET LTD to buy bulls and goats for slaughtering. With the anticipated profit from the two businesses he will educate his children, and he also hopes to buy a piece of land for farming.

loans.use: to buy bulls and goats for slaughtering.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilizers for the banana plantation

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is 38 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 1 child. 
Mary Jane has a retail shop that sells sacks of charcoal. She has had this business for 8 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy materials needed in making charcoal.
Mary Jane is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Mary Jane hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy materials needed in making charcoal

loans.name: Sami

texts.en: Sami is a 40 year old man. He is married with five sons and two daughters. he is a Palestinian National Authority employee with a decent salary. Sami wants to improve his family's living conditions by purchasing new home furniture such as: bedroom and dinning room furniture,..etc , but the amount of money he has isn't enough, so he needs to take a loan of $1,000 from FATEN. When Sami gets the loan, he will be able to purchase the necessary home furniture the family needs . Sami is photographed in a FATEN branch.

loans.use: To purchase new home furniture

loans.name: Kyebbumba Anti Hiv/aids Group

texts.en: Gereva wants to buy bulls to rear and sell during the festive season of Christmas. He joined a group to be able to access a loan. Age 45 years, he started his livestock rearing farm from sales of agricultural produce. He dreams of educating his six children and wants to acquire a motorcycle to ease his transport problem.

loans.use: to buy bulls for resale

loans.name: Vankan-Sekou Group

texts.fr: Le groupement VANKAN-SEKOU est formé de treize personnes qui habitent toutes dans le même quartier au Bénin et appartiennent à un même groupe de tontine. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Chantal est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. Chantal est âgée de 31 ans, et est mariée à un entrepreneur du nom de Raymond. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous à leur charge. Parmi les enfants, certains sont scolarisés. Chantal n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Depuis une vingtaine d’année, Chantal vend des ustensiles de cuisine et des vêtements dans son quartier ; ce qui permet d’assurer ensemble avec son mari les diverses charges de la famille. Chantal  achète ses produits au Bénin. C’est la première fois que Chantal et les autres membres du groupement VANKAN-SEKOU sollicitent un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Ce crédit leur permettra de renforcer leur activité et d'accroître leur fonds de roulement, afin de mieux répondre à la demande de leur clientèle.
texts.en:
The group VANKAN-SEKOU is comprised of thirteen persons who all live in the same district in Benin and who belong to the same revolving credit group. The group's representative, by the name of Chantal, is the one in the photo with her hand raised. Chantal is 31 years old and married to an entrepreneur by the name of Raymond. They have four children, all in their care. Some of the children are in school. 

Chantal did not attend school. For about twenty years, she has been selling kitchen utensils and clothing in her area; this enables her, along with her husband, to cover family expenses. She makes her purchases in Benin 

This is the first time that Chantal and the other members of the group VANKAN-SEKOU have requested a loan from ALIDé. This loan will allow them to bolster their business and to increase their working capital in order to respond further to customer demand.

loans.use: to buy clothing and kitchen utensils

loans.name: Juliri

texts.en:
Juliri is 39 years old and lives in the town of Tororo in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past six years, Juliri has been working hard to manage her clothes shop, which sells dresses and men's suits. 

To help expand her business, Juliri has requested a loan of 1,600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes, and will help Juliri to generate greater profits and get a contract to build a house. Juliri hopes that in the future she will be able to educate her children up to university level. 

Juliri is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Juliri who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy tools and pay for the gasoline for maintenance.

loans.name: Anas

texts.en:
Anas is a 24-year-old single man from Marka, Amman, Jordan.

Anas is a mechanic and is requesting a loan of 1500 JD to purchase spare parts for his store so that he can expand his business.

Anas is looking to expand the range of his mechanics shop.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and expand his business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy materials needed in making charcoal.

loans.name: Gabriel

texts.en:
Gabriel is married to Beth and together they have two children who are both in school. He has a food stall and has been in the business for the past two years. He gets a monthly income of KES 12,500 from the business.

This is his first loan term with KADET LTD. He will use the loan amount to buy items for the food stall and cereals for sale. He will enlarge the food stall with the anticipated profits. His dream is to own a restaurant.

loans.use: to buy food items like maize flour and wheat flour

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 33 years old and lives in the town of Bungokho in the Mbale region of Uganda. For the past two years, Robert has been working hard to manage his bar and lodge, which sells drinks and sodas to local customers. 

To help expand his business, Robert has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to construct more rooms in his bar, and will help Robert to generate greater profits and improve his family's welfare. Robert hopes that in the future he will be able to develop even more rooms on the lodge side of his bar. 

Robert is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Robert who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to construct more rooms in his bar

loans.name: Ma. Clarence

texts.en: Ma. Clarence is 39 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. Ma. Clarence has a shop that sells hot dogs, homemade sausage or longganisa and peanut butter. She has had this business for nine years. She requested a loan for 5,000 Philippines pesos to buy raw ingredients needed for making homemade sausage. Ma. Clarence has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Ma. Clarence hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients needed for making homemade sausage.

loans.name: Hovsep

texts.en: Hovsep is from the town of Gyumri in the Shirak region of Armenia.  He is married with three children – two daughters (sixteen and eighteen) and a nine-year-old son.  He has a high school education and has been trained as an auto mechanic.  Previously, he worked in that field.  For the past five years, however, Hovsep has been running a small shop.  It is hard work but he enjoys being a sole entrepreneur.  Hovsep would like to expand the types of food and household goods he sells.  He would like a loan to expand his store's products.  With this investment, Hovsep expects the shop income to increase by twenty-five percent.  He is planning and dreaming for all his children to attend university.  He likes living in Gyumri and looks forward to a bright future for his family.

loans.use: to purchase new products for the shop

loans.name: Raphael

texts.en:
Raphael is 33 years old; he is divorced from his wife and has a five-year-old child. He has been selling vehicle spare parts for the past five years. He has a monthly income of KES 10,000, which he uses for his child’s needs.

He is applying for his first loan with KADET LTD after being introduced by an existing KADET customer. Raphael will use the loan to buy wrenches, oil and wheels to add to his business. 

With the anticipated profit from the business he will educate his child. His hopes and dreams are to open a car wash business and expand the spare part selling business, which will help him improve his child's living standards.

loans.use: To buy wrenches, oil, and wheels to add to his business

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is 32 years old and lives in the town of Bungokho in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has four children with three of them currently in school. For the past ten years, Aisha has been working hard to manage her shop, which sells all types of shoes. 

To help expand her business, Aisha has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more pairs of shoes for resale and will help Aisha to generate greater profits and improve her family's welfare. Aisha hopes that in the future she will be able to continue to grow her business. 

Aisha is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Aisha who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more pairs of shoes for resale

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda and her husband own and manage a rice farming business to generate income. They have been farming for more than 20 years and usually earn a profit of 25,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) every harvest season. They use their income for their daily consumption and for allowance for their child. They aim to become financially stable to continue sending their child to school and to give him a bright future. 

Despite financial difficulties, they aim to expand their rice plantation to increase their yields. She is asking for additional capital of 20,000 PHP to buy fertilizers and pesticides for their rice farming business. She believes that her loan will help her to improve their rice farming business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides for a rice farming business

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is 42 years old is married with four children. She lives in the Philippines. For the past six years, she has run a shop where she sells canned, goods, snacks, and beverages. Janet has been a member of HSPFI since 2010.

Janet is requesting an 11,000 PHP loan to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Eman

texts.en: Eman is a 27-year-old married woman from Marka, Amman, Jordan. She is the mother of three children. Due to culturA. issues, the man in the picture is Eman's husband. Eman is sewing clothes from her home and she is requesting a loan of 499 Jordanian dinars to purchase a new sewing machine. Eman is looking to purchasing her own car and to expanding her business by purchasing more sewing machines.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine

loans.name: Kamene

texts.en:
Kamene is 49 years old and an enterprising business lady. She is married with five children aged 19, 17, 14, 11 and eight years, respectively. She has been running a green grocer business in an open air market for the past 21 years and has a monthly income of KES 30,000, which she uses to support her family.

She is applying for her second loan term from KADET LTD after repaying the previous loan successfully. Kamene will use the loan to buy green vegetables and fruits to add to her business. 

With the anticipated profit from the business she will educate her children. Her hopes and dreams are to open a retail shop and continue with the green grocer business which will help her improve the living standards of the family.

loans.use: To buy green vegetables and fruits to add to her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy soft drinks, bread, eggs, vinegar, and sugar to sell in her store

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 63 years old and is married to Thomas. Together they have five adult children. She sells fish and also farms and has been in the business for the past year. She gets a monthly income of KES 10,000 from the business.

This is her third loan term from KADET LTD. She will use the loan to purchase stocks of fish, fertilizer, and pesticides for her farm. 

She will buy another piece of land with the anticipated profits. Her dream is to support her grandchildren financially.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of fish, fertilizer, and pesticides for her farm.

loans.name: Kolin

texts.en:
Kolin is 48 years old and lives in the town of Bungokho in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has five children,  four of whom are currently in school. For the past fourteen years, Kolin has been working hard to manage her distillery, in which she makes a traditional Ugandan drink called Waragi. 

To help expand her business, Kolin has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more Waragi ingredients and will help Kolin to generate greater profits and improve her family's welfare. Kolin hopes that in the future she will be able to continue growing her business. 

Kolin is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves entrepreneurs like Kolin with small business who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients to distill a traditional Ugandan drink called Waragi.

loans.name: Ebtesam

texts.en: Ebtesam is a 36-year-old married woman from Marka, Amman, Jordan. She is the mother of four children. Ebtesam is requesting a loan of 500 Jordanian dinars to purchase new furniture for her house. One aspiration of Ebtesam is to do the needed maintenance for her home and get it painted. She is also looking to purchase a car.

loans.use: To purchase new furniture for her home

loans.name: Carmena

texts.en: Carmena is a married woman with five children. Carmena is 39 years old and resides in Calabayan, Ozamis City, in the Philippines. Carmena owns and operates a motorcycle transport business to earn a living. She's been in the business for five years. Each month, she earns PHP 35,000 doing this type of work. She requested a loan of PHP 50,000 to purchase additional vehicle spare parts. Carmena has been a member of GDMPC for almost three years. In the future, Carmena wants to build a house and have her children finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase additional vehicle spare parts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Policarpio

texts.en:
Policarpio is 66 years old and is married with seven children. He lives in the Philippines. For the past 20 years, he has run a shop where he sells cultured tilapia by the kilogram. He is a new member of HSPFI.

Policarpio is requesting a 5,000 PHP loan to buy fish feed for his cultured tilapia. In the future, he hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy fish feed for his farmed tilapia

loans.name: Lucrecia

texts.en:
Lucrecia, a widow with ten children, lives in Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sur where she has been selling bananacue to make a living for more than a year, earning about Php 3,000.00 per month to support her family.

A member of GDMPC for more than two years, Lucrecia has requested a loan of Php 5,000.00 to buy bananas and other cooking ingredients for her business. She intends to stand firm in her efforts to support her family, and she will work hard to expand the enterprise.

loans.use: to purchase bananas and other cooking ingredients.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase products for resale (flour, oil, beverages, stock, rice and others)

loans.name: Afeped (Missebo 2) Group

texts.fr: Le groupe AFEPED (MISSEBO 2)est formé de deux personnes qui habitent dans le même quartier. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Blandine Léonie, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo. C’est la deuxième fois que ce groupe sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue d’élever le niveau de leur activité. Blandine Léonie est âgée de 59 ans et est une veuve. Blandine Léonie a quatre enfants, mais deux restent encore à sa charge. Parmi les enfants, certains sont scolarisés. Blandine Léonie vit seule avec ses enfants à charge. Blandine Léonie a fréquenté l'école jusqu'au secondaire. Pour faire face à ses besoins et subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants, Blandine Léonie prépare et vend de la nourriture (riz) dans une école de son quartier, depuis une trentaine d'année. Parallèlement à cette activité, Blandine Léonie vend des accessoires pour yaourt et bissaps. Dans le souci de renforcer davantage son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Blandine Léonie désire élargir son activité. Pour ce faire, Blandine Léonie sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe AFEPED (MISSEBO 2), un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le premier crédit a été bien remboursé.
texts.en: The group AFEPED (MISSEBO 2) is composed of two persons who live in the same district. The group's representative, named Blandine Léonie, is the one in the photo with her hand raised. This is the second time this group has requested financial aid from ALIDé with the aim of boosting their business. Blandine Léonie is 59 years old and a widow. She has four children. Two of the children still remain in her care, and certain ones are in school. She lives alone with the children she supports. Blandine Léonie has attended middle school. To cope with her needs and those of her children, she has been making and selling food (rice) at a school in her area for about thirty years. Along with this work, she sells supplies for making yoghurt and bissaps (for example, beverages made from hibiscus flowers). Concerned about bolstering her business further and responding better to the requirements of her customers, she would like to expand. To do so, she and the other member of the group AFEPED (MISSEBO 2) are requesting a second loan from ALIDé. The first loan has indeed been repaid.

loans.use: to buy sauce condiments, rice and supplies for making yoghurt and refreshments

loans.name: Melda

texts.en:
Melda is 22 years old. She has been in the farming business for the past one year with a monthly income of KES 15,000 which she uses to cater to her basic needs.

She is applying for her first loan term from KADET LTD after being introduced by a KADET LTD staff member. Melda will use the loan to buy farm manure and seedlings for her farm. 

With the anticipated profit from the business, she will venture into pig rearing. Her hopes and dreams are to buy a piece of land and do farming on a large scale.

loans.use: To buy farm manure and seedlings for her farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase materials to build his home (windows, panes, cement, textured paint, beams, etc.)

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is 53 years old and a widow with three children, aged 30, 26 and 20 years. She owns a retail shop and has been a green grocer for the past eight years. She gets a monthly income of KES 15,000 from the business.


This is her fourth loan term with KADET. She paid her previous loans successfully. She will use the loan amount to purchase sugar, wheat flour, kerosene, sodas, tomatoes and vegetables.


She will use the anticipated profits to educate her grandchildren. Her dream is to open another shop for her son to manage.

loans.use: to buy sugar, wheat flour, kerosene, sodas, tomatoes and assorted vegetables

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita is 38 years old and is married with one child. She lives in the Philippines. For the past five years, she has operated a fishpond and she sells fish such as tilapia by the kilogram. Florita is a new member of HSPFI.

Florita is requesting a 5,000 PHP to buy fish feed for her farmed tilapia.

loans.use: to buy fish feed for her farmed tilapia

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 41 years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the past five years, Samuel has been working hard to manage his service shop, in which he does repairs on motorcycles, sells spare parts and charges batteries. 

To help expand his business, Samuel has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more spare parts and power inverters to help with charging batteries. The loan will help Samuel to generate greater profits and improve his family's welfare. Samuel hopes that in the future he will be able to begin preparing for old age and to finish paying the tuition for his child's school fees. 

Samuel is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves entrepreneurs like Samuel with small business who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more spare parts and power inverters to help with charging batteries.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en: Imelda is a married woman with three children. Imelda is 44 years old, residing at Segatic Diot, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Imelda owns and operates a farm, planting bananas to earn a living. She has been in this business for six years. Each month, she earns 15,000 PHP with this type of business. She requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase pesticides and costs paid in banana planting. Imelda has been a member of GDMPC for almost four years. In the future, Imelda wants to build a jewelry store and to finish educating her children.

loans.use: to purchase pesticides and costs paid in banana planting

loans.name: Esperanca

texts.pt:
Nasceu no Distrito de Chibuto, Provincia de Gaza, sul  de Moçambique, solteira e mae de 2 filhos  dos quais 1 frenquenta a Escola. Fez 3ª classe  e nao continuou por falta de condicoes financeiras pela parte dos pais. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e nao sustenta mais ninguem. 

Saiu de Chibuto para Boane, a procura de melhores condicoes de vida, é comerciante ha mais de 20 anos vende produtos variados e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 9.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum na sua conta bancaria.
Nunca teve emprestimo noutros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku atravez de uma amiga que tambem é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu quarto emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000.00mt, com qual pretende comprar material de construcao obra da sua casa (ferro, cimento, tinta, areia, barrotes e outros) para dar continuidade com a construcao da sua obra.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente e no futuro pretende concluir a sua casa e iniciar outras obras e para tal tenciona solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Esperança was born in the Chibuto district, Gaza province, in southern Mozambique.  She is a single mother of 2 children, one of whom attends school.  She attended school through the third grade but did not continue due to her parents' financial situation.  She owns the home where she lives with her family and she does not support anyone else.  

She left Chibuto for Boane in search of better living conditions.  She has been a merchant for more than 20 years, selling a variety of products.  She earns around 9.000.00mt per month, which she uses for household expenses and she saves some in her bank account.

She has never had a loan in another bank.  She learned about Hluvuku through a friend who is also a client.  This is her fourth loan with Hluvuku, in the amount of 20.000.00mt, which she will use to purchase materials (iron, cement, paint, sand, beams, etc.) to continue construction on her home.  

She promises to make her payments on time.  In the future she plans to complete her home and start other projects, and she intends to request more loans from Hluvuku for this purpose.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials for her home (iron, cement, paint, sand, beams, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages

loans.name: Ana

texts.pt:
Nasceu na cidade da Matola, Provincia de Maputo, sul  de Moçambique, casada e mae de 3 filhos  dos quais 2 frenquentam a Escola. Fez 3ª classe  e nao continuou por falta de condicoes financeiras pela parte dos pais. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e nao sustenta mais ninguem. 

É comerciante ha mais de 15 anos, vende frangos vivos em Moçambique e na Republica da Africa do sul, onde mensalmente consegue um rendimento de cerca de 20.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum na sua conta bancaria (BIM).
Nunca teve emprestimo noutros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku atravez de uma amiga que tambem é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu primeiro emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 18.000.00mt, com qual pretende comprar pintos, ração, vacinas para aumentar a quantidade da sua criaçaõ e consequentemente aumentar o seu rendimento.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente e no futuro pretende aumentar as suas capoeriras e a quantidade de frangos, para tal tenciona solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Ana was born in the city of Matola, Maputo province, in southern Mozambique.  She is married and has 3 children, 2 of whom attend school.  She attended school through the third grade but did not continue because her parents did not have the money.  She owns the home where she lives with her family and she does not support anyone else.  

For over 15 years she has been a merchant.  She sells live chickens in Mozambique and in the Republic of South Africa.  She earns 20.000.00mt per month which she uses for household expenses and savings in her bank account (BIM).

She has never had a loan in other banks.  She learned about Hluvuku through a friend who is also a client.  This is her first loan with Hluvuku, in the amount of 18.000.00mt, which she will use to purchase chicks, feed, and vaccines to increase her flock and increase her earnings. 

She promises to pay on time.  In the future she plans to expand her coops and quantity of chickens.  She plans to request more loans from Hluvuku for that purpose.

loans.use: to purchase, chicks, feed, and vaccines for raising chickens.

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson is married to Jane and together they have two children, who are both attending school. He runs a food kiosk and has been in the business for the past five years. He gets a monthly income of KES 80,000 from the business.

This is Nelson's first loan term with KADET. He will use the loan amount to add stock like sugar, maize flour, wheat flour, and meat, as well as renovate the kiosk.

With the anticipated profits, he will expand the premises of his kiosk to expand the business. His dream is to be able to cater for his family's needs.

loans.use: to increase stock of sugar, maize flour, wheat flour, and meat and to renovate the business premises

loans.name: Pedro

texts.pt:
Nasceu no Distrito de Manjacaze, Provincia  de Gaza, sul  de Moçambique, casado e pai de 11 filhos  dos quais 5 frenquentam a Escola. Fez 10ª classe e parou por falta de tempo. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e nao sustenta mais ninguem. 

Saiu de Manjacaze para Boane para continuar com os seus estudos, acabou aranjando em emprego no Ministerio da Educacao como professor e agora assume a funcao de director de uma Escola primaria. Exerce esta actividade ha mais de 20 anos  e tem um salario de 8.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum na sua conta bancaria (BCI).
Ja teve emprestimo noutros bancos (BIM) e pagou sem dificuldades, mais tarde conheceu a Hluvuku atravez de um colega que tambem é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu terceiro emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000.00mt, com qual pretende comprar material de construcao da sua casa (chapas, vidros, cimento, ferro, areia, barrotes e outros) para dar continuidade com a construcao da sua obra.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente e no futuro pretende concluir a sua casa e para tal tenciona solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Pedro was born in the district of Manjacaze, Gaza province, in southern Mozambique.  He is married and has 11 children, 5 of whom attend school.  He attended school through the 10th grade but stopped because he did not have enough time to go.  He owns the home where he lives with his family and he does not support anyone else.   

He left Manjacaze for Boane to continue his schooling.  He ended up finding work in the Ministry of Education as a professor and now he is the director of a primary school.  He has had this job for more than 20 years and has a salary of 8.000.00mt per month, which he uses for household expenses and savings in his bank account (BCI).  

He had a loan in another bank (BIM) and paid it off without any problems.  He later learned about Hluvuku through a colleague who is also a client.  This is his third loan with Hluvuku, in the amount of 20.000.00mt, which he will use to purchase materials (metal panels, glass panes, cement, iron, sand, beams, etc.) to continue construction on his home.  

He promises to make payments on time.  In the future he plans to complete construction on his home and he intends to request more loans from Hluvuku for that purpose.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials for his home (metal panels, glass panes, cement, iron, sand, beams, etc.)

loans.name: Flocerfida

texts.en:
This is Flocerfida, 61, resident of Taguig City, Philippines. She is married to Aniceto, and is the mother of their children. She, together with her husband and children, manages her own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses and support her children’s schooling. 

Flocerfida operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales everyday.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Flocerfida hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and so she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Hussain

texts.en:
Hussain has been an owner of a men's clothing shop since 2008. This borrower is from Iraq. He is 24 years old, married and the father of two children. He has more than four years' experience in his field. He has a deep understanding of local customers and knows about their needs. He has a good reputation and he is well known in the surrounding areas.

Hussain decided to apply for a $1,500 loan in order to make a sliding door for his shop. He is aiming to gain more profits to improve his family’s life.

loans.use: to make a sliding door for his shop.

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en: Leonida is 61 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married, has four children and earns a living by running a retail shop where she sells canned goods, snacks, spices and vegetables such as cabbage, radishes and squash. She has had this business for 10 years and is applying for a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy more canned goods, snacks and vegetables to sell to her customers. Leonida joined HSPFI last year and is committed to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and vegetables to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase construction supplies for his house (cement, iron, sand, stone, rafters, etc.).

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy iron rods

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en: Marissa is the optimistic and thrifty 36-year-old mother of two school-age children. Despite the many problems and difficulties she has encountered in life, she is determined to improve her family's life. For the last 15 years, she has earned a living as a farmer, planting and harvesting corn and vegetables. She hopes to have a good harvest in the coming year, and is applying for a loan for PHP 15,000 to buy seeds, fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer and pesticide for her farm.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is 42 years old and married to Bernard, and together they have three children aged 18, 14 and 7 years. She does poultry keeping and has been in the business for the past 3 years. She gets a monthly income of KES 32,000 from the business.

This is Ruth's third loan term with KADET. She paid his previous loans successfully. She will use the loan amount to purchase chicks to rear and sell later at a profit.

She will use the anticipated profit to open a retail shop. Her dream is to have a stable income.

loans.use: to purchase chicks to rear and sell later at a profit

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy materials to make more furniture to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past four years Francis has been working hard to manage his electronics shop, in which he repairs and sells both new and old radios, tvs, phones and other electrical appliances. 

To help expand his business, Francis has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more phones and spare parts for phones for the shop, and will help Francis to generate greater profits and install a new phone line in his office. Francis hopes that in the future he will be able to expand his market to neighboring areas. 

Francis is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves entrepreneurs like Francis with small business who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more phones and spare parts for phones.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is 31 years old, married, has one son and works for a private company that pays him a decent salary. He is applying for a loan for $1,000 from FATEN to make a series of repairs to his house, including painting and replacing the doors and windows. These repairs will allow his family to enjoy much better living conditions. Ahmad was photographed at our FATEN branch.

loans.use: to repair his house.

loans.name: Amos

texts.en: Amos is a thirty-eight-year-old married man with three children living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His family dream is educating his children and owning at least five motorcycles. He has been operating a retail shop and a motorcycle business for the last eight years. He faces challenges with high fuel costs. Amos needs the loan to buy another motorcycle so that he can increase his income.

loans.use: to buy another motorcycle.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is 43 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is widowed and has six children, four of whom are currently in school. For the past five years, Fatuma has been working hard to manage her business, in which she sells maize and produce. 

To help expand her business, Fatuma has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more bags of maize, and will help Fatuma to generate greater profits and transition into selling wholesale. Fatuma hopes that in the future she will be able to open other wholesale businesses. 

Fatuma is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small business entrepreneurs like Fatuma who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more bags of maize.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 28 years old and lives in the Philippines with her husband and three children. She earns a living by providing motorcycle (or habal-habal) services. She has been in this business for three years and is applying for a loan for PHP 15,000 to buy tools and gasoline. Grace has been a member of HSPFI since 2008 and is committed to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy tools and gasoline for her transportation service.

loans.name: Edson

texts.en: Edson is a 37-year-old single parent with two children living in a three-bedroom house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His family dream is to educate his children to higher levels of learning and to become a model farmer. He has been in the business of mixed farming for five years and has been challenged by the rainy season and the constant animal diseases. Edson needs the loan to plough the garden and buy iron sheets for his house

loans.use: to plough the garden and buy iron sheets

loans.name: Lanie

texts.en:
Lanie is married. She is 22 years old with two kids and they lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur.
Lanie sells fish in the market to earn a living and has had this business for more than 6 years. Each month, she earns Php 3,500 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan in the amount of Php 4,000.00 to purchase more fish and fishing materials to sell. Lanie has been a member of GDMPC for more than 2 years. Lanie's returns will be used for sending her two kids to school and to provide for their daily needs.

loans.use: to purchase more fish and fishing materials to sell

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has three children with two of them currently in school. For the past five years, Peter has been working hard to manage his retail shop where he sells food and home supplies to local customers. 

To help expand his business, Peter is requesting a 2,000,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to buy more essential commodities like sugar for resale. His loan will help Peter to generate greater profits and pay his son's primary school fees. Peter hopes that in the future he will be able to transition his business into wholesale.

Peter is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Peter who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy commodities such as sugar to sell

loans.name: Hinde-Alodoalome Group

texts.fr: HINDE-ALODOALOME est un groupe de six personnes, dont les membres cohabitent ensemble. La représentante du groupe, Pierrette Edwige (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est âgée de 44 ans et est mariée à un forgeron nommé Christophe. Le couple a quatre enfants, dont trois sont à leur charge. Certains des enfants sont scolarisés. Pierrette Edwige vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la maison. Pierrette Edwige n’a pas fréquenté l'école. Depuis environs dix sept ans, Pierrette Edwige vend des tissus dans un marché du Bénin. Pierrette Edwige s'approvisionne au Nigéria. C’est la deuxième fois que Pierrette Edwige et les autres membres du groupe HINDE-ALODOALOME sollicitent l’appui financier de ALIDé en vue de renforcer leur fonds de roulement et leur activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de leur clientèle.
texts.en:
HINDE-ALODOALOME Group is made up of six persons, who share a home. The group's representative, Pierrette Edwige (raising her hand in the photograph) is 44 years old, and married to a blacksmith named Christophe.

The couple has four children, out of whom they have to support three. Some children attend school. Pierrette Edwige lives together with her husband and children. The couple takes care of the various household expenses together

Pierrette Edwige never attended school. For approximately seven years, she's been selling fabrics at one of Benin's markets. She gets her supplies in Nigeria.

This is the second time that she and the other members of the group are seeking financial support from Kiva's partner, ALIDé, to bolster their working capitals and their businesses in order to better meet customer expectations.

loans.use: to buy fabrics

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en:
Jesca is 32 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is married and has seven children with six of them currently in school. For the past six years, Jesca has been working hard to manage her grocery store where she sells food and home supplies to local customers. 

To help expand her business, Jesca is requesting a 1,500,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to buy more food items for resale. Her loan will help her to generate greater profits and improve the quality of life for her family. Jesca hopes that in the future she will be able to open a wholesale shop.

Jesca is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Jesca who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy food items for resale

loans.name: Ivan

texts.en:
Ivan is 44 years old and lives in the town of Kamuli in the Jinja region of Uganda. He is married and has six children who are all currently in school. For the past 14 years, Ivan has been working hard to manage his clothing shop where he sells new clothes at the local market. 

To help expand his business, Ivan is requesting a 2,000,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to buy more women's clothing. His loan will help Ivan to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Ivan hopes that in the future he will be able to open up a poultry farm.
 
Ivan is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Ivan who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy women's clothing

loans.name: Felecitas

texts.en:
Felecitas is married, 47 years old, with 9 kids and she lives in Tukuran,  Zamboanga Del Sur.
Felecitas owns and operates farmland, planting crops to earn a living and has had this business for more than 9 years. Each month, she earns PHP 19,500 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan in the amount of PHP 16,000 to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Felecitas has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. Felecitas saves the profit for her 9 kids and to provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Sebastiano

texts.en: Sebastiano is a 60-year-old married man with ten children living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His family dream is to construct a big permanent house on his plot of land for renting and to own a large tea plantation. He is currently practicing mixed farming and he got start-up capital from farming. He has been challenged by the change of seasons, but desires to become a model farmer. Sebastiano needs the loan to prepare land for the next season and also to improve on his projects.

loans.use: to prepare land for the next season and also to improve on his projects

loans.name: Fawziya

texts.en:
Fawziya, a 44-year-old married woman, wants to change her old home furniture and purchase new furniture to improve her home's conditions. She wants to fulfill her family's needs for furniture such as bedroom furniture for her children, a kitchen table, etc. Fawziya is a conservative woman, so her husband, Helmi, is photographed in the FATEN branch instead. 

Fawziya is married with three sons and two daughters. Her husband is a Palestinian National Authority employee with a decent salary. The amount of money she has isn't enough to pay for furniture, so she needs to take out a loan of $1,000 from FATEN. When Fawziya gets the loan, she will be able to purchase the new home furniture she needs and let her family live in better and healthier conditions.

loans.use: to purchase new home furniture to replace the old.

loans.name: Mable

texts.en: Mable is a 38-year-old single mother with four children living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her family dream is to build rental houses and educate her children. She has been selling produce for the last five years. She started with 500,000 shillings, but now her business has over two million shillings. Her biggest challenges are the constant price changes and her dream is to own a big food store. Mable needs the loan to buy maize grains for selling.

loans.use: to buy maize grains for selling

loans.name: Mirvat

texts.en:
Mirvat is a 33-year-old married woman and is a mother of two beautiful children, who she works hard to provide for with the best living ever. Mirvat has been a hairdresser for 15 years; she is a hardworking woman with a very good reputation. Mirvat is very friendly with her customers; they enjoy her work and insist on supporting her to improve her business as much as she can.

Mirvat is an A. Majmoua borrower for the second time. Her previous loan helped in improving her business and her sociA. and financiA. situations. This time, Mirvat is requesting a loan from Kiva Partner A. Majmoua to make her children's dream come true. She intends to buy them their dream bedroom, instead of having to sleep on a mattress on the floor. She hopes this brings happiness to their hearts. 

Mirvat also hopes to expand her business through opening a speciA. faciA. department, in addition to tattoo and speciA. makeup departments.

loans.use: to buy a bedroom for her children

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 27 years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale region of Uganda. For the past two years, Robert has been working hard to manage his shop where he sells mattresses and plastic water drums. 

To help expand his business, Robert is requesting a 1,500,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to buy more mattresses and water drums. His loan will help Robert to generate greater profits and upgrade his business to wholesale. Robert hopes that in the future he will be able to build a permanent home on his plot of land and shift his mattress store into his home.

Robert is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Robert who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more mattresses and water drums

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 31 years old and lives in the town of Kamuli in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past nine years, Mariam has been working hard to manage her retail shop, where she sells different kinds of household supplies. 

To help expand her business, Mariam is requesting a 2,000,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to purchase rice and beans. Her loan will help Mariam generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Mariam hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a hardware business. 

Mariam is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Mariam who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase rice and beans

loans.name: Abdul

texts.en: Abdul is a 36-year-old married man with four children living in Kasese, Uganda. He has been selling engine oils and charging batteries for six years. He started with 300,000 shillings and now has 1,600,000 shillings as his working capital. His hardships are price fluctuations, inflation and customers not paying on time. His personal goals are educating children and expanding the business into new markets and moving the business to a more permanent location. Abdul needs the loan to buy engine oils and poultry birds.

loans.use: to buy engine oils and poultry birds

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is a 34-year-old single mother of two children living in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her dream is to build rental houses so she can earn income out of them. Agnes has been selling produce for the last three years. She started with a capital of 200,000, but now the business is worth 1,000,000. In spite of this, Agnes has been challenged by the high cost of rent and the rainy season, which makes transportation of the produce from the village difficult. She needs the loan to buy maize grains for selling.

loans.use: to buy maize grains for selling

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has two children who are both currently in school. For the past two years, Moses has been working hard to manage his stationary store, which offers services like photocopying and printing, and sells traditional stationary like books. 

To help expand his business, Moses has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more stationary like reams of paper and will help Moses to generate greater profits and buy a refrigerator. Moses hopes that in the future he will be able to finish building his house. 

Moses is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Moses who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more stationary like reams of paper

loans.name: Guljakan's Group

texts.en:
Guljakan is the leader of this group. She is 54 and married to a shepherd. This brave woman has raised five daughters and a son. All the children are married and live separately with their families. Guljakan owns 2.5 hectares of land, where she grows wheat. From time to time, she sells some part of the harvest to meet the family needs. With money received from the loan, Guljakan wants to purchase sheep to increase the number of livestock, which they breed and resell at a higher price after fattening. In the future, she wishes to leave a good inheritance to her children.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables for sale in his grocery shop

loans.name: Ganbold

texts.en: Ganbold is 38 years old and lives with his wife and three kids in a ger, a Mongolian yurt (traditional nomadic housing tent), in Hovd province, Mongolia. His wife helps him to operate the business. His two older kids are school students and the younger one goes to kindergarden. He started his metal household-goods-making business in 1998. He makes spoons, forks, cups, pot, and ovens. He has one employee and his wife sells the goods. Now that winter is approaching, customer demand is high, therefore he needs to keep up with the demand in order to be successful. He is a sharp and diligent man who says "My kids are growing and I need to be able to afford the college fee when my kids are old enough". He is requesting MNT 1,300,000 to buy raw materials to make goods.

loans.use: To buy raw materials to make goods

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter used the previous loan to buy chicks for his poultry project and pay school fees for his children. He has been doing well in the poultry project despite the increase in prices of poultry feeds. Because of the dream to educate his children, he has decided to modernize his farming practices by improving on his tomato gardens. Peter now needs the loan to buy chemicals for spraying the tomatoes, and to pay his workers.

loans.use: to buy chemicals to spray tomatoes, and to pay his workers.

loans.name: Dwighta

texts.en:
This is Dwighta, who is 55 and a resident of Taguig City, Philippines. She is single and manages her own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Dwighta operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5-pesos worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from this, she also retails mineral water for added income. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1,000 Philippines pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 30,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Dwighta hopes to be able to expand soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Dalaibaatar

texts.en: Mr. Dalaibaatar, 39, is a driver of a minivan used for passenger transportation around the district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has been doing his business during the past decade and always has a lot of passengers. Recently, he has bought a new minivan from his friend, but still he could not cover his car payment. Changing his minivan for a new one is very beneficial for his business earnings, and he can provide more secure and comfortable service to his passengers. Therefore, the loan Dalaibaatar is taking will be dedicated to covering the payment of his new minivan.

loans.use: To cover the payment of his new minivan.

loans.name: Fa-Nou Group

texts.fr: Le groupe FA-NOU est formé de trois personnes qui vivent dans le même quartier. La représentante de ce groupe, nommée Adjoa Bénédicte, est celle dont la main est levée sur la photo.
